results.title: Australia at work
results.creator_credit: Greg Shepherd, Mervyn Dober, Appleseed Productions and Focus Audio-Visual Services
results.brief_description: This series of four videos has been compiled from extensive footage of the working environment. Hundreds of Australians from all walks of life have been interviewed to paint a fascinating picture of the Australian working community.

results.title: Australian football
results.creator_credit: Stanley Moore, Ajax Films and Coca-Cola
results.brief_description: The great Australian game of football - of colorful crowds packing Melbourne Cricket Ground to watch their idols play. Players demonstrate the bounce, recovery, centre bounce, tackling, passing the ball, marking, various types of kick and the finer points of the game to youngsters at school. Includes sequences shot whilst important games were in progress.

results.title: Australia: a fair and reasonable community?
results.creator_credit: Greg Shepherd, Mervyn Dober, Appleseed Productions and Focus Audio-Visual Services
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Australia at work”.
A four part series examining Australians’ attitudes to work and to changes in the Australian workplace. This episode examines wealth and the distribution of wealth in Australian society. Though considered a fair and equitable society, the video introduces us to the people who are not involved in “wealth production”: the unemployed. An examination is made of the social welfare system in Australia and the importance of the Trade Union movement in fighting for the rights and for the safety of organised labour.

results.title: Australian dream
results.brief_description: Dorothy Stubbs is married to Queensland’s “Butcher of the Year”, Geoff Stubbs who is campaigning to be Prosperity Party Candidate for suburban Avon Heights. But Dorothy finds something missing in her life, especially when she attends a Sex Aids party and starts to fantasise about the male stripper there- Todd, (also horse-riding instructor, rock singer and petty thief). When Geoff invites the leader of the Prosperity Party to the monthly neighbourhood b-b-q at his house (with the theme “Come as Your Favourite Fantasy”) and Dorothy secretly invites Todd’s band, the dreams of both are destined to collide in an hilarious night of drunkenness and debauchery. Cast: Noni Hazlehurst, Graeme Blundell, John Jarratt, Barry Rugless.

results.title: Australian [colour] diary. No. 037. Country jazz
results.creator_credit: Bob Kingsbury, Gil Brealey and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: The 25th Australian Jazz Convention, 1970, brought 600 musicians and enthusiasts to Dubbo, N.S.W. This annual event startled many of the local inhabitants, especially those who watched the parade of musicians down the main street. Featured artists and groups were the Original Graeme Bell Australian Jazz Band, Allan Stott’s Hottentots, Lachie Thompson’s New Whispering gold Orchestra, Nick Polites and his New Year’s Revllers and the Dubbo Corps Salvation Army Band.

results.title: Australian Defence Scientific Service: 1969 report
results.creator_credit: John Carter, Malcolm Otton and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: The Australian Defence Scientific Service undertakes research in various fields. In the laboratories of the Weapons Research Establishment and other Commonwealth scientific areas, shows the research in thin film optics, and high-speed photography in the testing of explosives and munitions.

results.title: Australia: a technological society?
results.creator_credit: Greg Shepherd, Mervyn Dober, Appleseed Productions and Focus Audio-Visual Services
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia at work”.
A four part series examining Australians’ attitudes to work and to changes in the Australian workplace. This final episode examines the increasing impact of technology throughout all Australian industry. Increases in productivity are linked to the growing mechanisation of industries and a resultant change to traditional work practices. As a direct result of increased mechanisation, workers now need to retrain and be educated in using new technologies. Through interviews with employees and management the impact of technology on working life is discussed, as well as the effects technology will have on Australian society in the future.

results.title: Australia: room down under
results.creator_credit: Dan Klugherz and Westinghouse Broadcasting Company for Intertel
results.brief_description: This American assessment of Australia gives special attention to our migrant programme and the subtle ways immigrants are changing Australia’s way of life. The question of the White Australia Policy, the contrasts of great cities and desolate interior, and to the arts and sports. Australia as it appears to a newcomer is seen through the impressions of a migrant girl in her unrehearsed discussions with her Australian boyfriend. Film includes interviews with swimming coach Don Talbot, filmmaker Tim Burstall.

results.title: Australia: eye of the storm
results.creator_credit: Ashley Smith, Jeni Clevers, Klaus Toft, Mark Lamble, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Channel 4, Granada Media and Telcast International
results.brief_description: This four part series describes the powerful climate systems that batter Australia and how they affect it’s weather, wildlife and people. Using state-of-the-art cinematography, computer graphics and satellite images, each program traces the development of one climactic force and explains how Australia’s plants and animals cope with these long-term weather events. Forces examined include: ‘La Nina’ (combination of torrential rainfall, cyclones and massive floods); ‘Southern Exposure’ (sudden storms from Antarctica and the Southern Ocean); ‘El Nino’ (droughts and bushfires from heat and lack of water) and ‘Monsoon’ (rainstorms and accompanying sea conditions). Also included in this video is a short program called ‘Stormchasers’ which looks at the making of the other four programs.
